content:
re :Each time nothing seems to change and when I open the program it sits there for a while connecting then nothing arrives no errors or anything it just sits there and doesnt pull in any new emails.

Just a thought but as you use Pop, it is possible there is what I call a logjam caused by one email in 'Inbox' or sometimes it can be in 'Spam/Junk' folder and that email for some reason cannot get downloaded and therefore is blocking the system.

  • Access webmail via browser.
  • Empty the 'Spam/Junk' folder.
  • In 'Inbox' look for the oldest email which did not get downloaded to Pop.
  • Either delete it OR move it to another folder.

Then either restart Thunderbird to see if it auto connects and downloads auto OR try the 'Get Messages'.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
re: Why can I not select the order in which I wish incoming messages to be displayed?

If you are already viewing the list of incoming emails in the 'Table View' (one email per line) then you will see columns headers at the top. You can click on a column header to reverse the sort. eg: If you want emails sorted by Date, then click on the 'Date' column header. If emails are sorted by Date but new is at the bottom and you want them at the top then click on the 'Date' column header to reverse whatever is currently displayed. This means you can choose to 'Sort by' Date and also choose whether it is ascending or descending order.

If you are viewing email list in 'Card View' (each email uses 3 lines in list) then you will not see the column headers. This is what David was discussing.

re :I used to be able to click on a heading 'view, which would bring up several options including 'sort by'.

You are talking about the 'Menu Bar' toolbar. You would need to enable it.

On the far right of the new 'Unified Toolbar' is the 'Menu app' icon - it has 3 horizontal lines

  • Click on 'Menu app' icon
  • Click on 'View'
  • Click on 'Toolbars'
  • Click on 'Menu bar'

please answer some queries so we have a better understanding of what you are looking at.

The Message List - Are you using 'Card View' or 'Table View' ? Have you enabled the 'Menu Bar' toolbar ?


re :Those headers are not there anymore Do you mean...you have enabled the 'Menu Bar' toolbar, then use 'View' > 'Sort by' and you see many of the column header options are greyed out - not possible to select ? If yes: It means you have not selected to enable them in the 'Table View', so only the column headers you have already chosen to be displayed in Message List will be enabled for selection in the 'Sort by' list. Why ? because it's not possible to sort by an option which is not already been enabled in the Message List.

It would help if you posted some images so we can see what you are seeing.

petewalton said
Yes, I cannot change that. Also, I am unable to select 'from' as a choice.

Is 'From' already selected as a column header at the top of the 'Message List' ? If no then 'View' > 'Sort by' will be greyed out because you cannot sort by something that has not been selected in the 'Message List as a column header.

So, at top of 'Message List' look on far right for icon with tooltip 'select columns to display'. Click on that icon and select the 'From' column header so it displays at top of Message List as a column header. Then you will find View > Sort by will offer 'from'.

content:
Se stai usando IMAP, verifica che i messaggi non siano cancellati da altre postazioni con cui accedi alla stessa casella, ad esempio dallo smartphone. IMAP infatti precede la sincronizzazione di tutti i messaggi su tutti i dispositivi collegati alla stessa email.

Sempre con IMAP, verifica che in menu > impostazioni account > NOME_ACCOUNT > Sincronizzazione e archiviazione sia attiva la voce Non eliminare alcun messaggio

Se invece usi POP3 come protocollo, vai in menu > impostazioni account > NOME_ACCOUNT > Spazio su disco e verifica che sia attiva la voce Non eliminare alcun messaggio

Infine puoi anche creare delle copie manuali della posta che vuoi conservare. Basta copiare i messaggi all'interno della cartella Cartelle locali di Thunderbird.

I file che contengono email sono detti mbox e sono quelli senza estensione tipo UNICREDIT o UNICREDIT1. I file con estensione .msf invece non contengono email ma sono degli indici.

content: Regarding your first question: If you migrate away from Office 365 to another email provider, then you can still use the email addresses with Thunderbird. You will have to change the server details in Account Settings -> Server Settings and Account Settings -> Edit SMTP server with the new credentials as described by the new provider.

content: Gmail has increased its security on incoming mail. Gmail sees your your sending domain name and the domain of the email host as being different and rejects the mail. Your email provider needs to make security adjustments to their server. This is not something you can do. This is not uncommon where an individual pays for a web host for a private domain. The best you can do is to check that you are authenticating on the SMTP settings.

content:
If you opted for Thunderbird to save passwords then they are here:

In Thunderbird

  • Settings > Privacy & Security
  • Scroll to 'Passwords' section
  • Click on 'Saved Passwords' button
  • Click on 'Show Passwords' button

As passwords have been altered via webmail, you will need to alter the stored password for both incoming and outgoing smtp. You will see two lines - one will be either 'mailbox:// account... for pop OR imap://account... for IMAP and the other will be smtp://account...

  • Right click on relevant line and select 'Edit Password'
  • Clear all data and then carefully enter new password.
  • Once both lines have been correctly updated...click on 'Close'

I would suggest at this point to Exit Thunderbird - wait a few moments for all preferences to be updated to relevant files then start Thunderbird. Thunderbird should then check all accounts using the new password.

content: Justr to be a bit clearer, I see the line beginning 'smtp' but the line beginning 'pop', which you mention, is not there at all
creator: peter.bavington

content:
peter.bavington said
Justr to be a bit clearer, I see the line beginning 'smtp' but the line beginning 'pop', which you mention, is not there at all

In stored passwords - The incoming line for a pop account start with 'mailbox://....'

If you have no line starting with 'mailbox://account.... then no password was stored. In this case you would expect Thunderbird to try to access server and server ask for password. Hence the prompt for password pop up window.

You could try completely removing all stored passwords: Click the "Remove all" button, then the "Close" button then restart Thunderbird and it should prompt for password, at which time you enter the new password you created and select the checkbox to remember password before clicking on OK.

If that does not work then try the following: In Thunderbird

  • Help > Troubleshooting Information
  • Under 'Application Basics' section - half way - Profile folders - click on 'Open Folder'

A new window opens showing the contents of your profile folder.

  • Exit Thunderbird now this is important

There have been many cases where password is NOT stored and you are NOT getting the prompt for password and the 'pkcs11.txt' is the only file that needs to be deleted. This usually occurs maybe after a major update or if you move the profile from one operating system to another. So first only try deleting this one file.

  • pkcs11.txt

Start Thunderbird and see if offers password prompt, enter password, select checkbox to remember password before clicking on OK.

Please note: if you have any clean up product like CCleaner, WiseCleaner or any anti-virus product that offers clean up of files, then I strongly advise you do not let these products clean up anything in your profile name folder as they have a habit of deleting session files, passwords, etc and you do not want this to occur in Thunderbird.
creator: Toad-Hall

content: https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/password-manager-remember-delete-change-tb
creator: MattAuSupport

content: I am not aware of accounts using separate passwords, so more information may help. On your question, NO, you should never attempt to use one SMTP server for multiple accounts. That is a recurring problem that is posted here. You should verify that you have a separate SMTP server with unique name in Documentation field of SMTP settings pane and connected to the appropriate account. Generally, you need just one password for each account. For more help, please share more info on the problem.
creator: davidsk

content:
"That is a recurring problem that is posted here." The answer isn't found looking at the list of passwords, it's under the single Outgoing Server (SMTP) button. Well, thanks (Ah-ha!), I finally understand the issue.

If there are separate email addresses using the "same server" from the email provider's point of view (eg smtp.emailprovider.net) there need to be be separate servers defined from the client (Thunderbird's) point of view.

1. Open Thunderbird. 2. Click Tools > Account Settings (or) click View settings for this account from Home. 3. Click Outgoing Server (SMTP). 4. Click Edit. 5. Change the description to the account name 6. Fill in the Server Name (can be the same for multiple accounts from the same email provider) 7. Change the port to 465 or 587 (or whatever is recommended) 8. Make sure SSL/TLS is selected under Connection security (or whatever is recommended) 9. Change the Authentication method to Normal Password. 10. Change the User Name to the account email address Click OK. THEN click ADD... and enter the information for the next account. Repeat for each account.

Now there is a server defined for each account. Then when sending an email and the password fails, Thunderbird will ask for the password. Enter the password and check "save in password manager". Do that for each account.

Hope that helps.

creator: davidsk

content:
SOLVED (Workaround really) Set Connection Security to STARTTLS

Despite ISP's (shaw.ca) recommendation to use SSL/TLS, use STARTTLS instead.

It appears Shaw's SMTP (shw-obgw-4003a.ext.cloudfilter.net) server rejects Thunderbird's SSL/TLS connections with error "500 Bad chars in command". Switching to STARTTLS will prompt for the email password on next send. Clicking the Save Password option makes it visible in the Saved Logins file.

Suggested changes for Thunderbird: 1) Resolve incompatibilities in smtp SSL/TLS protocol between Thunderbird and ISPs 2) Provide details in the dropped connection pop-up harvested from the SMTP error packet 3) Return add/copy/paste options to the Saved Logins dialog

Sincere thanks to Mozilla and the open-source support community!
creator: rvdann2014

content: I'm pleased that all is well. Regarding Thunderbird, it is not in error. What you are experiencing is that many email providers are changing their requirements and not telling users. What I suggested has been successful on many accounts. And, thanks for sharing your success.
creator: davidsk

content:
There is no such thing as a thunderbird account because Thunderbird is not a server nor does it offer thunderbird email address.

Thunderbird allows you to create a mail account for an existing email address. This means you do not need to logon to a webmail account via a browser to read/send emails, you can do it in Thunderbird. Depending upon what the server offers you can usually create a 'Pop' or an 'Imap' mail account.

First - make sure 'Thunderbird' is set up as an allowed app otherwise the computer Firewall may block access to the internet.

  • Exit Thunderbird if it is running.
  • Access Firewall (this is either the computer default Firewall or if you have installed an Anti-Virus product then it might be controlling the Firewall)
  • Set up the Thunderbird program as an allowed program.


Q: Have you created a mail account in Thunderbird for your email address? If no: In Thunderbird

  • Click on the Menu app (3 lines) icon and select 'New Account'
  • Select 'Existing Email'
  • Enter your name, full email address, password (same one you use to access webmail account), select the checkbox to remember password and click on 'Continue'.

Thunderbird will attempt to locate the server settings as it has a library of all the most commonly used server settings. By default Thunderbird normally selects the server settings for an 'Imap' mail account, so if you want different you must reselect the 'Pop' option before selecting to create the account.

If yes: Did you create a Pop or an Imap mail account ? Please post the following info if you have already created the mail account. In Thunderbird

  • Click on the Menu app (3 lines) icon
  • Help > Troubleshooting Information
  • Scroll down to 'Mail and News Accounts' section
  • Copy all the information in that area and paste that info into this forum question.

Then I check you have got all the correct settings.
creator: Toad-Hall

content: Just to clarify: Thunderbird is an email client with no authority of any kind over anyone's email accounts. What you may be experiencing is learning how to use Thunderbird. For example, if this is an IMAP account, you might try highlighting the account name in left side of main view, rightclick and select 'subscribe' to see if your folders show.
